children.value: The tidyverse is a collection of R packages that transform and visualize data. All packages of the tidyverse share very similar syntax and ideologies.
There are many other packages with more specialized functions in the tidyverse. In this chapter, we focuses on two packages:
is used for grammar of data manipulation.
helps you to create tidy data or data where each variable is in a column, each observation is a row and each value is a cell. You can use them to solve the most common data manipulation challenges.
You can install the core tidyverse packages with:

## ✓ ggplot2 3.3.5     ✓ purrr   0.3.4
## ✓ tibble  3.1.6     ✓ dplyr   1.0.7
## ✓ tidyr   1.1.4     ✓ stringr 1.4.0
## ✓ readr   2.1.1     ✓ forcats 0.5.1

## ── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
## x readr::edition_get()   masks testthat::edition_get()
## x dplyr::filter()        masks stats::filter()
## x purrr::is_null()       masks testthat::is_null()
## x dplyr::lag()           masks stats::lag()
## x readr::local_edition() masks testthat::local_edition()
## x dplyr::matches()       masks tidyr::matches(), testthat::matches()
You can also load specific library separately, for example,
provides a selection of tools for the most common data wrangling tasks.
There are a bunch of useful commands to transform and aggregate data in R.
: pick particular variables from your data.

## # A tibble: 6 × 1
##   country    
##   <chr>      
## 1 Afghanistan
## 2 Afghanistan
## 3 Brazil     
## 4 Brazil     
## 5 China      
## 6 China
: extract observations from the data based on a given condition

## # A tibble: 6 × 4
##   country      year type            count
##   <chr>       <int> <chr>           <int>
## 1 Afghanistan  1999 cases             745
## 2 Afghanistan  1999 population   19987071
## 3 Brazil       1999 cases           37737
## 4 Brazil       1999 population  172006362
## 5 China        1999 cases          212258
## 6 China        1999 population 1272915272
: sort your data based on one or more variables

## # A tibble: 12 × 4
##    country      year type            count
##    <chr>       <int> <chr>           <int>
##  1 Afghanistan  1999 cases             745
##  2 Afghanistan  2000 cases            2666
##  3 Brazil       1999 cases           37737
##  4 Brazil       2000 cases           80488
##  5 China        1999 cases          212258
##  6 China        2000 cases          213766
##  7 Afghanistan  1999 population   19987071
##  8 Afghanistan  2000 population   20595360
##  9 Brazil       1999 population  172006362
## 10 Brazil       2000 population  174504898
## 11 China        1999 population 1272915272
## 12 China        2000 population 1280428583
: add new variables or change existing variables
: takes existing data and groups specific variables together for future operations. These two functions are often used together with other
functions. We will introduce them with the
function creates a new dataframe based on the argument provided.

## # A tibble: 2 × 3
##   type            min        max
##   <chr>         <int>      <int>
## 1 cases           745     213766
## 2 population 19987071 1280428583
You can summarize the data in different ways based on the groupings and different argument you included.
: a convenient way to get a sense of the distribution of values in a data set.

## # A tibble: 3 × 2
##   country         n
##   <chr>       <int>
## 1 Afghanistan     4
## 2 Brazil          4
## 3 China           4
Often you will need information from multiple datasets in your data analysis. It is important to learn different types of joins to accommodate different needs in your tasks.

We are going to use the following tables in our example. Consider there are 4 students in a class and they submitted homework 1 and homework 2. The tables contains their scores for the homeworks (gradebook) and not everyone submitted their homework during the semester.
Mutation joins return a copy of the dataset that has been augmented.
Inner joins retain only rows that exists on both datasets.

## # A tibble: 2 × 4
##   name     student_no marks.x marks.y
##   <chr>         <dbl>   <dbl>   <dbl>
## 1 Alphonso        456      80      85
## 2 Philip          102      34      97
When we perform inner join by
, R only returns rows that exists in both data set. When we do inner join with our
’s marks will show up since they are the only ones that submitted both homeworks.
Left joins starts with the left data set (
) and search in the right data set looking for the same values of
to add to the left data set.

## # A tibble: 3 × 4
##   name     student_no marks.x marks.y
##   <chr>         <dbl>   <dbl>   <dbl>
## 1 Alphonso        456      80      85
## 2 Daisy           100      65      NA
## 3 Philip          102      34      97
When we do left join with our

gradebooks, we will only consider those students who submitted homework 1 and look for their marks in homework 2. Melinda’s result will not be included in the join even though she has submitted her homework 2, while Daisy will have
Right joins starts with the right data set (homework2) and search in the left data set looking for the same values of
to add to the right data set.

## # A tibble: 3 × 4
##   name     student_no marks.x marks.y
##   <chr>         <dbl>   <dbl>   <dbl>
## 1 Alphonso        456      80      85
## 2 Philip          102      34      97
## 3 Melinda         432      NA      56
When we do right join with our

gradebooks, we will only consider those students who submitted homework 2 and look for their marks in homework 1. Daisy’s result will not be included in the join even though she has submitted her homework 1, while Melinda will have

## # A tibble: 4 × 4
##   name     student_no marks.x marks.y
##   <chr>         <dbl>   <dbl>   <dbl>
## 1 Alphonso        456      80      85
## 2 Daisy           100      65      NA
## 3 Philip          102      34      97
## 4 Melinda         432      NA      56
All the submissions with the corresponding mark are included in the full join of the gradebook.
Filtering joins return a copy of the dataset that has been filtered.
The semi join returns a filtered version of the left data set based on matching entries in the right data set.

## # A tibble: 2 × 3
##   name     student_no marks
##   <chr>         <dbl> <dbl>
## 1 Alphonso        456    80
## 2 Philip          102    34

## # A tibble: 2 × 3
##   name     student_no marks
##   <chr>         <dbl> <dbl>
## 1 Alphonso        456    85
## 2 Philip          102    97
Now, let’s say we want to know who didn’t submit homeworks. The anti join will return the rows in the left data set that doesn’t have an entry in the right data set.

## # A tibble: 1 × 3
##   name  student_no marks
##   <chr>      <dbl> <dbl>
## 1 Daisy        100    65

## # A tibble: 1 × 3
##   name    student_no marks
##   <chr>        <dbl> <dbl>
## 1 Melinda        432    56
Raw data that we acquired can often be messy and complicated. The tidyr package allows you to wrangle messy datasets into nice and tidy ones.

A tidy data format has a rectangular shape which means it has columns, rows, and cells, just like in a spreadsheet. Each column should hold a single variable, each row should hold a single observation and each cell should hold a single value.

The example below shows the same information (country, year, population, and number of cases) organised in 3 different ways.
Examine each of the table.

## # A tibble: 12 × 4
##    country      year type            count
##    <chr>       <int> <chr>           <int>
##  1 Afghanistan  1999 cases             745
##  2 Afghanistan  1999 population   19987071
##  3 Afghanistan  2000 cases            2666
##  4 Afghanistan  2000 population   20595360
##  5 Brazil       1999 cases           37737
##  6 Brazil       1999 population  172006362
##  7 Brazil       2000 cases           80488
##  8 Brazil       2000 population  174504898
##  9 China        1999 cases          212258
## 10 China        1999 population 1272915272
## 11 China        2000 cases          213766
## 12 China        2000 population 1280428583
Table 3 only |  Try again! Each cell in a tidy data format should hold only a single value. The column
contains data with two values (one divided by the other) and is converted to characters.
Table 1 and 3 |  Try again! Each cell in a tidy data format should hold only a single value. The column
in Table 3 contains data with two values (one divided by the other) and is converted to characters.
Table 2 and 3 |  Try again! Each cell in a tidy data format should hold only a single value. The column
in Table 3 contains data with two values (one divided by the other) and is converted to characters. Table 2 contains two variables under the same column ‘type’.

Sometimes raw data may have multiple variables or multiple values (not the same variable) in the same column, or sometimes you may want to merge multiple columns into one. Here are a few commands that can be helpful in manupulating the data into a tidy format:
: separating multiple variables in one column to different columns
: merging multiple columns into one, inserting underscore
as a separator between the two inputs.
: separating multiple observations in the same cell. We pass the messy column name and a string to use as a separator.

column contains both the number of cases and the size of the populations.
We want to separate the
argument expects a vector of column names. The
argument expects the non-alphanumeric character (a charater that is not a letter or a number) that we split upon. The
argument is set to TRUE here so that R will try and convert to better types after the split.
column can be combined to give a
argument here is what comes in between the values from different columns. If we don’t want anything in between, we can use "".
In table 6, there are multiple observations in the same cell in each row of
. We would like to separate them.

## # A tibble: 6 × 3
##   country      year  cases
##   <chr>       <int>  <int>
## 1 Afghanistan  1999    745
## 2 Afghanistan  2000   2666
## 3 Brazil       1999  37737
## 4 Brazil       2000  80488
## 5 China        1999 212258
## 6 China        2000 213766
Two common problems in raw data set:
some of the column names are not really names of variables, but
when an observation is scattered across multiple rows.
To tackle these problems, you will need
is a great example of data that needs
. Here you see that the case count of each country is separated into two columns because they are from different years.

The first argument is the vector of column names that are actually values not variables.
The second argument is the name of the variable to move the column

to.
The third argument is the name of the variable to move the column

## # A tibble: 6 × 3
##   country     year   cases
##   <chr>       <chr>  <int>
## 1 Afghanistan 1999     745
## 2 Afghanistan 2000    2666
## 3 Brazil      1999   37737
## 4 Brazil      2000   80488
## 5 China       1999  212258
## 6 China       2000  213766
In table 2, each observation is a certain country in a certain year. However, the observation is spread across two rows since there are

## # A tibble: 12 × 4
##    country      year type            count
##    <chr>       <int> <chr>           <int>
##  1 Afghanistan  1999 cases             745
##  2 Afghanistan  1999 population   19987071
##  3 Afghanistan  2000 cases            2666
##  4 Afghanistan  2000 population   20595360
##  5 Brazil       1999 cases           37737
##  6 Brazil       1999 population  172006362
##  7 Brazil       2000 cases           80488
##  8 Brazil       2000 population  174504898
##  9 China        1999 cases          212258
## 10 China        1999 population 1272915272
## 11 China        2000 cases          213766
## 12 China        2000 population 1280428583
The first argument is the column to take variable

.

: fill the missing values using the last observation carried forward. It has a

frontmatter.title: Chapter 6: Data Wrangling
frontmatter.description: In this chapter, you will learn to use tidyr and dplyr from the tidyverse in R.
